title: Mark Wood (explorer)
text:
Mark Wood <a href="Fellow%20of%20the%20Royal%20Geographical%20Society">FRGS</a> (born 1966), is a <a href="British%20people">British</a> <a href="explorer">explorer</a>, <a href="Public%20speaker">professional speaker</a>, expedition leader, and <a href="author">author</a>. He served in the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> in the Second Battalion, <a href="Royal%20Regiment%20of%20Fusiliers">Royal Regiment of Fusiliers</a>, and as a <a href="firefighter">firefighter</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Berkshire%20Fire%20and%20Rescue%20Service">Royal Berkshire Fire and Rescue Service</a>. He subsequently became an <a href="explorer">explorer</a>, and expedition leader where he has trained and led teams for major <a href="Polar_regions_of_Earth">Polar</a> and <a href="mountain">mountain</a> expeditions in extreme environments such as the <a href="Arctic%20Circle">Arctic Circle</a>, the <a href="Himalayas">Himalayas</a>, <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a>, and the Canadian and Norwegian High Arctic to raise awareness of <a href="Global_warming">climate change</a> and creates very large virtual classrooms in order to talk to schools and children about these issues.
Early life and education.
Mark was born in <a href="Coventry">Coventry</a> and attended two local schools: Stivichall Junior School and Coventry Finham Park Comprehensive School. Both schools are in <a href="Coventry">Coventry</a>, <a href="Warwickshire">Warwickshire</a>, England.
Military.
Mark served in the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> in the Second Battalion, of the <a href="Royal%20Regiment%20of%20Fusiliers">Royal Regiment of Fusiliers</a>, UK. He was in the <a href="military">military</a> for a number of years and was awarded the <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20II%20Golden%20Jubilee%20Medal">Queen Elizabeth II Golden Jubilee Medal</a>.
Firefighter.
Once he left the military he became a <a href="firefighter">firefighter</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Berkshire%20Fire%20and%20Rescue%20Service">Royal Berkshire Fire and Rescue Service</a>. 
Expeditions and exploration.
As an expedition leader and an <a href="Exploration">explorer</a> he has since 2003 been to various <a href="Polar_regions_of_Earth">Polar</a> regions ranging from reaching the <a href="Magnetic%20North%20Pole">Magnetic North Pole</a>, the <a href="Geomagnetic%20North%20Pole">Geomagnetic North Pole</a> twice, and solo expeditions to both the <a href="North_Pole">Geographic North Pole</a> and the <a href="South%20Pole">South Pole</a>. He has worked with the <a href="BBC">BBC</a> and <a href="Channel%205%20%28British%20TV%20channel%29">Channel 5</a> on various <a href="Documentary_film">documentaries</a>, having trained teams of people to undertake expeditions, and led expeditions in the extremes of the planet. His <a href="Documentary_films">documentaries</a> range from: the life of <a href="Sled_dog">dog teams</a> in <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a>, surviving solo in the <a href="Polar_regions_of_Earth">Polar</a> extremes, the reality of <a href="global%20warming">global warming</a> and its effect on the <a href="Arctic%20Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a> en route to the <a href="North%20Pole">North Pole</a>.
 More recently the aim of his expedition is to explain, to children in their <a href="classrooms">classrooms</a>, using the medium of <a href="Skype">Skype</a> combined with <a href="film">film</a> and <a href="sound">sound</a>, during his expeditions, the effects of <a href="global%20warming">global warming</a> in the <a href="Polar_regions_of_Earth">Polar</a> regions where the effects of climate change and <a href="global%20warming">global warming</a> are clearly evident. As all of his expeditions are connected with climate change and to empower the younger generations he works with the <a href="The%20Prince%27s%20Trust">The Prince's Trust</a>, he's a scout leader for the 1st Pillerton Scout Group, a patron of the Children's University, an explorer for IGGY.
